maml:description.maml:para: Escape names containing special characters that are not allowed in a path.

Certain characters are not allowed in names used in paths because they have special meaning. Some examples are the colon drive separator and the forward and back slash path separators. The following characters are converted to the %XX form: \*/:<>|?[]
Using the -Undo parameter to unescape an escaped name.
Name to escape
Undo the escape operation
Name to escape
Undo the escape operation
String or array of Strings.
Array of Strings

dev:remarks.maml:para: Escape the instance name SERVER\INSTANCE.
SERVER%5CINSTANCE
Escape the array of instance names.
SERVER%5CINSTANCE,SERVER%5CINSTANCE2
Escape instance SERVER\INSTANCE, then undo the operation.
SERVER\INSTANCE
Escape-SQLdmName is used to escape the backslash used in the instance name. It can also be used to escape the backslash used in Windows user and group names.

maml:description.maml:para: Get a list of available SQL Servers.
Get a list of SQL Servers being advertised on the network.
Return SQL Servers on the machine where this machine only.
Return SQL Servers on the machine where this machine only.
The SqlServerInstanceInfo object holds basic information about a SQL Server returned from the SMO enumerate server functions.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Return a list of SQL Servers running on the local machine.
Name : SQLSERVERA Server : SQLSERVERA Instance : Version : 9.00.3042.00 IsLocal : True
Return a list of all known SQL Servers.

Name : WSV03 Server : WSV03 Instance : Version : IsLocal : False
Name : WSV04 Server : WSV04 Instance : Version : IsLocal : False

maml:description.maml:para: Grant or change the permissions a user has to manage a monitored instance in SQL Diagnostic Manager.
Grant or change the permissions a user has to manage a monitored instance in SQL Diagnostic Manager.

Path to the SQL Diagnostic Manager user being granted permissions. If the Name parameter is not specified then Path must include the Monitored Instance the user is being granted permission. The path name must be located on an SQLDM drive.
Permission to grant the user for the selected instances. View and Modify are the only valid values.

Path to the SQL Diagnostic Manager user being granted permissions. If the Name parameter is not specified then Path must include the Monitored Instance the user is being granted permission. The path name must be located on an SQLDM drive.
Tag or list of tags to assign permissions to. The tags specified must already exist.
Permission to grant the user for the selected instances. View and Modify are the only valid values.

Path to the SQL Diagnostic Manager user being granted permissions. If the Name parameter is not specified then Path must include the Monitored Instance the user is being granted permission. The path name must be located on an SQLDM drive.
Name of the SQL Diagnostic Manager Monitored Instance the user is being granted permissions. If Name is specified then the Path parameter must specify the user being granted permission.
Permission to grant the user for the selected instances. View and Modify are the only valid values.

Path to the SQL Diagnostic Manager user being granted permissions. If the Name parameter is not specified then Path must include the Monitored Instance the user is being granted permission. The path name must be located on an SQLDM drive.
Permission to grant the user for the selected instances. View and Modify are the only valid values.
Tag or list of tags to assign permissions to. The tags specified must already exist.
Name of the SQL Diagnostic Manager Monitored Instance the user is being granted permissions. If Name is specified then the Path parameter must specify the user being granted permission.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Grant View permissions to instance 'AServer' to user 'AUser'.
Grant Modify permissions to instance 'AServer' to Windows user 'MyDomain\AUser'. Note the use of the Escape-SQLdmName command to handle the backslash in the Windows user name.
Grant user fred's permissions to instances tagged as Prod.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a drive for connecting to the SQLDM Repository.
Creates a drive for connecting the the SQLDM Repository. The drive allows you to query SQLDM configuration information using the SQLDM PowerShell Provider.
Name of the new drive.
SQL Server hosting the SQLDM Repository.
Name of the SQLDM Repository database.
Credentials used to connect to the SQL Diagnostic Manager Repository when using SQL Authentication.
Name of the new drive.
SQL Server hosting the SQLDM Repository.
Name of the SQLDM Repository database.
Credentials used to connect to the SQL Diagnostic Manager Repository when using SQL Authentication.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create a new SQL Diagnostic Manager drive called 'dm' that is connected to the SQLdmRepository database on the MYSQLDMSERVER SQL Server using Windows Authentication.
Name Provider Root ---- -------- ---- dm SQLdm dm:\

Create a new SQL Diagnostic Manager drive called 'dm' that is connected to the SQLdmRepository database on the MYSQLDMSERVER SQL Server using SQL Authentication. PowerShell will prompt for the password.

maml:description.maml:para: Add a new instance to SQL Diagnostic Manager to be monitored.
Adds a new instance to SQL Diagnostic Manager to be monitored and start monitoring the instance.

The path to the new instance for SQL Diagnostic Manager to monitor. If the instance name contains special characters then the name should be escaped. The current directory or path name must be located on an SQLDM drive.
Credential object that contains the user and password used for SQL Authentication.
Specifies how often (in minutes) scheduled data collection takes place.
Specifies how often (in minutes) database statistics collection takes place.
Use the credentials of the SQLDM Collection Service to connect to the monitored instance when collecting statistics.
Encrypt the data between the SQLDM Collection Service and the Monitored Instance.
When specified with the EncryptConnection parameter, the SQL Server will not validate the certificates sent from the client but the data will still be encrypted.
Disables the collection of extended session data used primarily by the History Browser in the Desktop Client.
Disables the collection of replication statistics for servers that are utilizing replication.
Disables the use of Ole Automation for collecting statistics.
List of tags assigned to this Monitored Instance. The specified tags must already exist.
Sets scheduled maintenance mode to Never. SQLDM will collect data according to its normal scheduled collection interval.
Sets maintenance mode to Always. Scheduled collection will not occur.
Sets Maintenance mode to Once. Scheduled collection will occur once at the specified time and will end at the specified time.
Sets maintenance mode to Recurring. Maintenance mode will start on the specified days at the selected time for the specified duration.
Specified the days of the week that Recurring maintenance mode will be effective.
Specifies the start time for recurring maintenance mode.
Specifies the length of time that recurring maintenance mode will be last.
Specifies the date time that one time maintenance mode will start.
Specifies the date time that one time maintenance mode will end.
Select option to disable OS metrics.
Configure OS metrics collection through OLE automation.
Configure OS metrics collection through direct WMI.
Connect using the SQLDM Collection Service Account.
Type WMI Login Name to collect OS metrics.
Type WMI Password to collect OS metrics.
Enable the query monitor.
Disable the query monitor.
Query monitor will capture statements.
Query monitor will capture batches.
Query monitor will capture stored procedures and triggers.
Enable monitoring of non-query activities.
Disable monitoring of non-query activities.
Query monitor will capture deadlock events.
Query duration filter in milliseconds.
CPU usage filter in milliseconds.
Logical disk read filter.
Physical disk write filter.
List of application names to exclude from the query monitor.
List of databases to exclude from the query monitor.
List of SQL statements to exclude from the query monitor.
Days of the week to perform quiet time collection.
Time of day for quiet time collection to occur.
Quiet time minimum table size (kilobytes) to collect reorganization statistics.
List of databases to exclude from quiet time data collection.

The path to the new instance for SQL Diagnostic Manager to monitor. If the instance name contains special characters then the name should be escaped. The current directory or path name must be located on an SQLDM drive.
Credential object that contains the user and password used for SQL Authentication.
Specifies how often (in minutes) scheduled data collection takes place.
Specifies how often (in minutes) database statistics collection takes place.
Use the credentials of the SQLDM Collection Service to connect to the monitored instance when collecting statistics.
Encrypt the data between the SQLDM Collection Service and the Monitored Instance.
When specified with the EncryptConnection parameter, the SQL Server will not validate the certificates sent from the client but the data will still be encrypted.
Disables the collection of extended session data used primarily by the History Browser in the Desktop Client.
Disables the collection of replication statistics for servers that are utilizing replication.
Disables the use of Ole Automation for collecting statistics.
List of tags assigned to this Monitored Instance. The specified tags must already exist.
Sets scheduled maintenance mode to Never. SQLDM will collect data according to its normal scheduled collection interval.
Sets maintenance mode to Always. Scheduled collection will not occur.
Sets Maintenance mode to Once. Scheduled collection will occur once at the specified time and will end at the specified time.
Sets maintenance mode to Recurring. Maintenance mode will start on the specified days at the selected time for the specified duration.
Specified the days of the week that Recurring maintenance mode will be effective.
Specifies the start time for recurring maintenance mode.
Specifies the length of time that recurring maintenance mode will be last.
Specifies the date time that one time maintenance mode will start.
Specifies the date time that one time maintenance mode will end.
Select option to disable OS metrics.
Configure OS metrics collection through OLE automation.
Configure OS metrics collection through direct WMI.
Connect using the SQLDM Collection Service Account.
Type WMI Login Name to collect OS metrics.
Type WMI Password to collect OS metrics.
Enable the query monitor.
Disable the query monitor.
Query monitor will capture statements.
Query monitor will capture batches.
Query monitor will capture stored procedures and triggers.
Enable monitoring of non-query activities.
Disable monitoring of non-query activities.
Query monitor will capture deadlocks.
Query duration filter in milliseconds.
CPU usage filter in milliseconds.
Logical disk read filter.
Physical disk write filter.
List of application names to exclude from the query monitor.
List of databases to exclude from the query monitor.
List of SQL statements to exclude from the query monitor.
Days of the week to perform quiet time collection.
Time of day for quiet time collection to occur.
Quiet time minimum table size (kilobytes) to collect reorganization statistics.
List of databases to exclude from quiet time data collection.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Add a new instance named INSTANCE1 to SQL Diagnostic Manager.
Add a new instance named SERVERA\INSTANCE1 to SQL Diagnostic Manager. The Escape-SQLdmName command is used to handle the use of a backslash in the instance name.

maml:description.maml:para: Add a new user to SQL Diagnostic Manager.
Add a new user to SQL Diagnostic Manager.
Path to the SQL Diagnostic Manager Login to add. The path includes the login name of the user. The current directory or path parameter must be located on an SQLDM drive.
The user being created is an SQL Login. If the Password parameter is not specified, PowerShell will prompt for the password.
The login specified is a Windows Group. The Password parameter is not allowed for Windows Group logins.
The login specified is a Windows User. The Password parameter is not allowed for Windows User logins.
The password to use for a SQL Login user.
The user will be granted administrator privileges.
Comment assigned to any permissions granted to this user.
Path to the SQL Diagnostic Manager Login to add. The path includes the login name of the user. The current directory or path parameter must be located on an SQLDM drive.
The user being created is an SQL Login. If the Password parameter is not specified, PowerShell will prompt for the password.
The login specified is a Windows Group. The Password parameter is not allowed for Windows Group logins.
The login specified is a Windows User. The Password parameter is not allowed for Windows User logins.
The password to use for a SQL Login user.
The user will be granted administrator privileges.
Comment assigned to any permissions granted to this user.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- Example 1 --------------
command:example.dev:code: New-SQLdmUser -Path fred -SQLLogin -Password xxxx -Comment "Fred is an admin"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create a new user called Fred that uses SQL Authentication.
Create a new user called mydomain\fred that uses Windows Authentication. The Escape-SQLdmName command is used to escape the backslash in the Windows user name.

maml:description.maml:para: Remove an instance from being monitored by SQL Diagnostic Manager.
Remove an instance from being monitored by SQL Diagnostic Manager.

Path to the SQL Diagnostic Manager Monitored Instance to remove. If the instance name contains special characters, such as a backslash, then the name should be escaped. The current directory or path name must be loacated on an SQLDM drive.
Deactivates the instance from monitoring by SQL Diagnostic Manager. The data is retained in the repository for reporting purposes.

Path to the SQL Diagnostic Manager Monitored Instance to remove. If the instance name contains special characters, such as a backslash, then the name should be escaped. The current directory or path name must be loacated on an SQLDM drive.
Deactivates the instance from monitoring by SQL Diagnostic Manager. The data is retained in the repository for reporting purposes.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Removes the instance named SERVERA from SQL Diagnostic Manager.
Removes the instance named SERVERA from SQL Diagnostic Manager but retain its data for reporting. The Escape-SQLdmName command is used to handle the backslash in the instance name.

maml:description.maml:para: Remove a user from SQL Diagnostic Manager.
Remove a user from SQL Diagnostic Manager.
Specifies a path to the SQL Diagnostic Manager users to be removed. Wildcards are permitted. The current directory or path parameter must be located on an SQLDM drive.
Specifies a path to the SQL Diagnostic Manager users to be removed. Wildcards are permitted. The current directory or path parameter must be located on an SQLDM drive.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Remove user fred from SQL Diagnostic Manager.
Remove Windows user MyDomain\AUser from SQL Diagnostic Manager.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a users permissions to a specified monitored instance in SQL Diagnostic Manager.
Removes a users permissions to a specified monitored instance in SQL Diagnostic Manager.
Path to an user\instance to revoke permissions. If the Name parameter is specified then the Path should identify a user. The current directory or path parameter must be located on an SQLDM drive.
Path to an user\instance to revoke permissions. If the Name parameter is specified then the Path should identify a user. The current directory or path parameter must be located on an SQLDM drive.
Name of the instance to revoke a users permissions to. If Name is specified then the Path parameter should identify a user otherwise the Path should identify an User\Instance.
Path to an user\instance to revoke permissions. If the Name parameter is specified then the Path should identify a user. The current directory or path parameter must be located on an SQLDM drive.
Tag or list of tags to revoke permissions to. The tags specified must already exist.
Path to an user\instance to revoke permissions. If the Name parameter is specified then the Path should identify a user. The current directory or path parameter must be located on an SQLDM drive.
Name of the instance to revoke a users permissions to. If Name is specified then the Path parameter should identify a user otherwise the Path should identify an User\Instance.
Tag or list of tags to revoke permissions to. The tags specified must already exist.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Revoke user fred's permissions to instance ServerA.
Revoke user fred's permissions to instance ServerA.
Revoke user fred's permissions to instances tagged as Prod.
Revoke Windows user MyDomain\UserA permission to ServerA\Instance1. Note the use of the Escape-SQLdmName command to handle the backslash in both the user and instance names.

maml:description.maml:para: Enable or disable application security in SQL Diagnostic Manager.
Enable or disable application security in SQL Diagnostic Manager.
Specifies the path of the AppSecurity object in the SQL Diagnostic Manager Provider. The current directory or path parameter must be located on an SQLDM drive.
Enable application security. This parameter is mutually exclusive with the Disabled parameter.
Disable application security. This parameter is mutually exclusive with the Enabled parameter.
Specifies the path of the AppSecurity object in the SQL Diagnostic Manager Provider. The current directory or path parameter must be located on an SQLDM drive.
Enable application security. This parameter is mutually exclusive with the Disabled parameter.
Disable application security. This parameter is mutually exclusive with the Enabled parameter.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Enable SQL Diagnostic Manager Application Security.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the logging level of the SQL Diagnostic Manager provider
Sets the logging level of the SQL Diagnostic Manager provider. This command is only used for debugging purposes and should only be used at the request of IDERA Technical Support.
List of loggers to apply the trace level settings to. The default is the Root logger.
Tracing level used to control messages sent to the log file.
Tracing level used to control messages sent to the console.
List of loggers to apply the trace level settings to. The default is the Root logger.
Tracing level used to control messages sent to the log file.
Tracing level used to control messages sent to the console.
Set the common properties of a monitored instance in SQL Diagnostic Manager.
Set the common properties of a monitored instance in SQL Diagnostic Manager.

The path to the Monitored Instance to be changed. If the instance name contains special characters then the name should be escaped. The current directory or path parameter must be located on an SQLDM drive.
Credential object that contains the user and password used for SQL Authentication.
Specifies how often (in minutes) scheduled data collection takes place.
Specifies how often (in minutes) database statistics collection takes place.
Use the credentials of the SQLDM Collection Service to connect to the monitored instance when collecting statistics.
Encrypt the data between the SQLDM Collection Service and the Monitored Instance.
When specified with the EncryptConnection parameter, the SQL Server will not validate the certificates sent from the client but the data will still be encrypted.
Enable or disable the collection of extended session data used primarily by the History Browser in the Desktop Client.
Enable or disable the collection of replication statistics for servers that are utilizing replication.
Disables/Enables the use of Ole Automation for collecting statistics.

List of tags assigned to this Monitored Instance. This parameter differs from the AddTags parameter in that the Tags parameter sets the list of tags whereas AddTag adds to the existing list of tags that may already be set. The Tags, AddTag and RemoveTag parameters are applied in Tags, AddTag, RemoveTag order. Any tags that are specified must already exist.

List of tags to add to the monitored instance. This parameter differs from the Tags parameter in that the Tags parameter sets the list of tags whereas AddTag adds to the existing list of tags that may already be set. The Tags, AddTag and RemoveTag parameters are applied in Tags, AddTag, RemoveTag order. Any tags that are specified must already exist.
List of tags to remove. The Tags, AddTag and RemoveTag parameters are applied in Tags, AddTag, RemoveTag order.
Sets scheduled maintenance mode to Never. SQLDM will collect data according to its normal scheduled collection interval.
Sets maintenance mode to Always. Scheduled collection will not occur.
Sets Maintenance mode to Once. Scheduled collection will occur once at the specified time and will end at the specified time.
Sets maintenance mode to Recurring. Maintenance mode will start on the specified days at the selected time for the specified duration.
Specified the days of the week that Recurring maintenance mode will be effective.
Specifies the start time for recurring maintenance mode.
Specifies the length of time that recurring maintenance mode will be last.
Specifies the date time that one time maintenance mode will start.
Specifies the date time that one time maintenance mode will end.

Configure OS metrics collection through OLE automation.
Configure OS metrics collection through direct WMI.
Connect using the SQLDM Collection Service Account.
Type WMI Login Name to collect OS metrics.
Type WMI Password to collect OS metrics.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Update the credentials used for instances INSTANCE1,INSTANCE2 and INSTANCE3 to use SQL authentication and set a new login and password. PowerShell will prompt you for the password.
Update the credentials used for instance SERVERA\INSTANCE1 to use Windows Authentication. Note the use of the Escape-SQLdmName command to handle the backslash in the instance name.

maml:description.maml:para: Set the properties of a user in SQL Diagnostic Manager.
Set the properties of a user in SQL Diagnostic Manager.
Specifies the path to the user to change in the SQL Diagnostic Manager Provider. Wildcards are permitted. The current directory or path parameter must be located on an SQLDM drive.
Enable the specified SQL Diagnostic Manager user.
Disable the specified SQL Diagnostic Manager user.
Grant or remove administrator rights to the SQL Diagnostic Manager user.
Specifies a comment to be set on all permissions defined for this SQL Diagnostic Manager user.
Specifies the path to the user to change in the SQL Diagnostic Manager Provider. Wildcards are permitted. The current directory or path parameter must be located on an SQLDM drive.
Enable the specified SQL Diagnostic Manager user.
Disable the specified SQL Diagnostic Manager user.
Grant or remove administrator rights to the SQL Diagnostic Manager user.
Specifies a comment to be set on all permissions defined for this SQL Diagnostic Manager user.
Specifies the path to the user to change in the SQL Diagnostic Manager Provider. Wildcards are permitted. The current directory or path parameter must be located on an SQLDM drive.
Enable the specified SQL Diagnostic Manager user.
Disable the specified SQL Diagnostic Manager user.
Grant or remove administrator rights to the SQL Diagnostic Manager user.
Specifies a comment to be set on all permissions defined for this SQL Diagnostic Manager user.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- Example 1 --------------
command:example.dev:code: Set-SQLdmUser -path \AppSecurity\bozo -Disabled -Comment "Bozo is disabled for clowing around."

dev:remarks.maml:para: Disable the Set SQL Diagnostic Manager user bozo.
Enable SQL Diagnostic Manager user fred and give him administrator rights.
Disable the SQL Diagnostic Manager user mydomain\fred. Note the use of the Escape-SQLdmName command to handle the backslash in the qualified Windows user name.
